title: Family in race against time to raise £140k for little boy's second round of pioneering cancer treatment
text:

A little boy with leukaemia is in a race against time as his family try to raise £140,000 so he can undergo a second round of life-saving treatment in America. 
Kind-hearted well-wishers donated more than £150,000 last year to send Liverpool fan Charlie Fearns, 11, to Seattle for pioneering Car T-cell therapy after he was diagnosed with the condition for a third time. 
But his parents Sophie and Rob, from Litherland in Merseyside, have now learned that the treatment, which uses a patient’s own immune system to attack the cancer, has failed – and a second attempt will cost another $187,000 - about £150,000. 
Cells taken from Charlie’s body during his first stay in Seattle can be used for another two months – and after this further treatment will cost £450,000. 
Rob told the Liverpool Echo : “The cells that they took from Charlie only have an eight-month window even though they’ve been frozen. We’re now on month six, so we have two more months. Read More Charlie Fearns, 11 (Photo: Charlie's Chance) (Photo: Charlie's Chance) 
“That doesn’t mean that if we don’t get the money it won’t happen, but it will mean taking more cells and the funds we have to raise will go up to £455,000.” 
The Fearns family told how they were determined to stay positive in an emotional post on the Charlie’s Chance appeal Facebook page last week. 
They wrote: “We were so shocked because he seemed to be doing so well and everything was going to plan but everything happens for a reason I suppose. 
“After speaking to Charlie’s haematologist the current plan is to return to Seattle to have a second infusion in the hopes that it will work. (Photo: Charlie's Chance) 
“So for now as we plan more events to fundraise for further treatment it doesn’t mean we stop helping other families in our position. It just means that we will concentrate on getting Charlie to Seattle again for now. 
“Please say your prayers, light your candles and if you would like to help with fundraising it will be greatly appreciated. Thanks as always for your continued support. 
“We just plod on. It’s just another hiccup on this journey to getting Charlie better. 
“Stay positive always.” Read More Mum's fury after tot's chicken pox pictures used by Facebook scammers who claim he has cancer for 'likes' 
Liverpool FC legend Steven Gerrard was among the kindhearted Scousers who supported Charlie last year, making a donation of £25,000. 
Charlie’s family and friends have managed to raise £1,500 in just a few days for the new appeal and are setting up a new online fundraising page. (Photo: Charlie's Chance) Robbie Fearns from Netherthon(centre),with his son Charlie, 9 (Photo: Liverpool Echo) 
Mum Sophie raised £200 through a car boot sale on Sunday and supporters are planning a skydive in Blackpool on March 10. 
Rob said: “We had been taking on the role of helping other families through Charlie’s Chance but now we are in this position we need to concentrate on Charlie. 
“We have been trying to give it a push in the last few days on Twitter and Facebook. We’re also starting a new fundraising page, because at the moment people might see that it’s at £160,000 and it could stop them from donating. 
“The support from everyone has been incredible – that’s never been in doubt from day one – and we want to thank them for it.” 
Updates on Charlie’s Chance and fundraising events can be found at https://www.facebook.com/CharliesChancefoundation or @Charlieschance on Twitter. 
A new fundraising page is in the process of being set up, but donations can be made through the first Charlie’s Chance appeal page at https://www.gofundme.com/charlie-schance Like us on Facebook
